transcripts.text: Hi, I'm Eduardo Naret with Campus Reform.  Today we're at the University of Tampa asking students about student loan debt and how it should be paid for.  So how much student loan debt do you have?

A lot.  Yep.  I think about $5,000 right now.  Probably a lot.  None.  About $13,000.  I think $20,000, $4,000.  Not a lot.  I don't know.  As of right now, I'm not really sure, but I'm a majority on scholarships.  None at the moment, no.
So there have been a lot of talks in society and in politics about the federal government wiping out student loan debt.  Does that sound like a good idea to you?  Would you before that?

Yes, 100%.  Yeah.  Yeah, I would.  Absolutely.  Yeah.  Yeah, totally.  Who wouldn't want less debt?  I think that everybody that goes to school should be able to go to school debt-free and be able to start off their career with no debt to owe to anybody.
Are you in favor of getting rid of student loan debt?

Yeah, I mean, it's a lot of money to come out of college with.  I guess you could raise taxes or something for other people or something.  I don't know, but that's like other people paying for your stuff, you know?
The federal government wiping out student loan debt.  Would you be in favor of such a plan?
Yes, because we need to get an education and every job that we need requires a degree and people can't always afford it and it puts us in debt forever.

So since you don't have student loan debt, something we're asking students is, would you be willing as someone who has no debt to pay a little bit more so that some of your peers who do have debt could get that erased off?  Would you be willing to maybe pay more tuition, pay more taxes so that someone could get their debt lowered?  Probably, maybe, yeah.  Maybe.  What's the part of you that maybe is a little hesitant about that?
Because I have to make my own money.  So if I make my money, I kind of want to keep my money that I make and not have to give it to my friends.  No.  Why not?
